wikitext.*:
'''Tol Withernon'''<ref>{{PE|11}}, p. 3</ref> might have been an island off the east coast of [[Tol Eressëa]], according to the early version of the [[legendarium]] associated with ''[[The Book of Lost Tales]]''.<ref name="Wit"/>

== Etymology ==
The name ''Tol Withernon'' is in [[Gnomish]]. The first element of the name is ''[[tol]]'' ("an isle with high-steep coasts")<ref>{{webcite|author=[[Paul Strack]]|articleurl=https://eldamo.org/content/words/word-2651735891.html|articlename=G. ''tol''|website=Eldamo|accessed=21 October 2024}}</ref>; however, the second part, ''Withernon'', is unclear.<ref>{{webcite|author=[[Paul Strack]]|articleurl=http://eldamo.org/content/words/word-2109179987.html|articlename=G. ''Tol Withernon (ar lim gardhin arthi)''|website=Eldamo|accessed=22 April 2022}}</ref>

== Inspiration ==
Tol Withernon might have been inspired by the town of [[wikipedia:Withernsea|Withernsea]] in [[wikipedia:Yorkshire|Yorkshire]], where, not far from it, [[Tolkien]] was stationed during [[wikipedia:World War I|World War I]].<ref>[[John Garth]], ''[[Tolkien and the Great War]]'', "Part three: Tol Withernon and Fladweth Amrod", p. 234</ref> While the town of Withernsea isn't located on an island presently, a local tradition claims that at some point in history it actually was an island.<ref name="Wit">[[John Garth]], ''[[Tolkien and the Great War]]'', "Part three: Tol Withernon and Fladweth Amrod", p. 236</ref>
